awd_titl_txt: Bioinspired selective anion incarceration by nanojars
awd_abstract_narration:
Anions are negatively charged chemical structures that are ubiquitous in Nature.  They play an essential role in the metabolism of living organisms. Anions such as phosphate and nitrate provide essential nutrients for agricultural crops and are therefore widely used in fertilizers.  Inorganic anions, including the highly toxic chromate, are also used in industrial processes and are sources of environmental pollutants. The excessive accumulation of inorganic anions in water could harm the environment by causing eutrophication of lakes and rivers and by poisoning the groundwater that supplies drinking water.  Prof. Gellert Mezei's group at Western Michigan University designs and synthesizes a unique class of anion-binding agents, termed 'nanojars'.  By studying the interactions of anions with these nanojars, the team aims to gain a better fundamental understanding of the factors governing selective recognition of anions and to provide insight to the future design of highly efficient anion-binding agents, not only for removing toxic anions from water, but also for recovering valuable anions, such as phosphate.  This project also provides research opportunities to high school and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups, offers education of the general public about Science through public events such as the "Chemistry Day at the Museum", and promotes collaborations with the industrial sector.

Selective extraction of specific anions from water is a challenging task, especially in the case of hydrophilic oxyanions of high charge density. Such anions, including phosphate and chromate, are strongly bound by water and are difficult to transfer into a water-immiscible, hydrophobic phase, from which they could be recovered or properly disposed of.  With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Prof. Mezei's group investigates anion encapsulation in nanojars to understand the structural intricacies needed for designing highly selective anion-binding agents. The nanojars are nanometer-sized supramolecular structures with a hydrophilic anion-binding pocket lined with hydrogen-bond donors and a hydrophobic, rigidifiable outer shell.  They offer a promising compromise between the large size of anion-binding proteins (which are impractical for large scale, industrial applications) and the poor selectivity of small-molecule anion receptors in general.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background

Anions (negatively charged molecules) are ubiquitous in Nature and many of them, including chloride, sulfate, phosphate and bicarbonate, play crucial roles in biochemical processes (in living organisms) as well as biogeochemical cycles (in the environment). Yet, excessive accumulation of these anions in water bodies (wells, lakes, rivers, wetlands) can pose a health risk or be detrimental to local ecosystems. Other anions, such as chromate, arsenate and selenate, which originate from industrial activities as well as natural minerals, are highly toxic to living organisms even in small amounts. Therefore, the removal of certain anions from water bodies is essential for protecting the environment and the well-being of humans and livestock. The binding and efficient removal of these anions from water is often very challenging because they are very hydrophilic (have high affinity for water) and are difficult to extract. Another challenge is the selective extraction of trace amounts of target anions in the presence of large amounts of innocuous anions.

 

Intellectual Merit

Funded by NSF, we developed a novel class of anion extraction agents termed “nanojars”, which possess a number of distinctive features compared to other known anion extraction agents. Nanojars have a striking affinity for highly hydrophilic anions and allow for the efficient extraction of anions from water into organic solvents, from which they can be recovered and either properly disposed of or recycled (such as in the case of phosphate, which is an important fertilizer in agriculture). For example, we achieved for the first time the removal of chromate and arsenate ions from contaminated water by liquid-liquid extraction to residual levels below the EPA limits in drinking water (<100 and <10 parts per billion, respectively). Nanojars are entirely selective for highly hydrophilic anions in the presence of less hydrophilic anions. For example, chromate can be selectively extracted from a mixture containing a large excess of nitrate. Furthermore, the selectivity of nanojars can be tuned toward certain hydrophilic anions (such as sulfate) in the presence of other hydrophilic anions (such as carbonate), by chemically modifying the outer shell of nanojars.

 

We demonstrated that nanojars can incarcerate not only small inorganic anions, such as the ones mentioned above, but also organic phosphonate anions with large substituents. Moreover, we discovered that contrary to previous beliefs that they can only bind anions with 2− and 3− charge, nanojars also bind singly charged (1−) anions such as toluenesulfonate. The latter is a result of the aromatic interactions between the substituent on the anion and the outer shell of the nanojar, in addition to the hydrogen bonding interactions between the anion and the inner cavity of the nanojar. The discovery that anion binding in nanojars is not restricted to small inorganic anions opened up a completely new area for anion binding and extraction using nanojars, given that many pollutants (e.g., detergents, surfactants and dyes) are large sulfonated or phosphonated molecules.

 

This grant allowed for an in-depth analysis of nanojars using a variety of characterization techniques, including mass spectrometry, variable-temperature nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography, UV-visible spectroscopy and thermogravimetry. In particular, single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments revealed important details about the intricate structure of nanojars and led to a better understanding of the molecular basis of anion binding and selectivity in nanojars.

 

The current NSF grant already resulted in 18 publications in peer-reviewed journals, and several others are in preparation for publication. The results have also been disseminated at numerous presentations at international, national and regional conferences, universities and national laboratories.

 

Broader Impacts

This NSF grant provided support and/or training and professional development for six graduate and eleven undergraduate students (including four and five students traditionally underrepresented in higher education, respectively), who contributed directly to this project; many of them have already co-authored publications resulting from their research on nanojars. Several other students benefited from the project and contributed indirectly by conducting research on related topics. The grant also supported yearly outreach events, such as “Sparking Young Children's Interest in Science through Chemical Demonstrations” at a local museum, and to students from a local middle school, aimed at educating the general public about the importance of Chemistry in their everyday life and well-being, and increasing the number of students pursuing careers in science. Collaborations with local industries were established, which provide internships and job opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students.
